speaker: narrator

utterance: That's just what I have done.
speaker: a lady in black

utterance: I was a Union woman, in the Confederacy. I couldn't talk; I had to write. I was in the siege of Vicksburg from beginning to end.
speaker: a lady in black

utterance: Leave your manuscript with me. If, on examining it, I find I can recommend it to a publisher, I will do so. But remember what I have already told you the passage of an unknown writer's work through an older author's hands is of no benefit to it whatever. It is a bad sign rather than a good one. Your chances of acceptance will be at least no less if you send this to the publishers yourself.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Dress me no dresses. Story me no stories. There's not one of a hundred of them that does not lack something essential, for want of which they are good for naught. Keep them for after-dinner chat; but for the novelist they are good to smell, not to eat. And yet — tell me your story. I have a use for it a cabinet of true things that have never had and shall not have a literary tool lifted up against them; virgin shells from the beach of the sea of human events. It may be I shall find a place for it there.
speaker: narrator

utterance: I have a faint impression that you will find something very much like that in one of Lever's novels.

And yet, see with what truth the lot of the countess is described! How happy she was in her emblazoned coach, and her jewels, her laces, her dresses of velvet and brocade! Ah, Françoise!
of the two destinies I choose that one.
speaker: Suzanne

utterance: And the other: how she was punished for her plebeian tastes!
speaker: Suzanne

utterance: So, my dear Suzanne, you would not marry
speaker: Alix

utterance: A man not my equal—a workman? Ah! certainly not.
speaker: Suzanne

utterance:
I know very well that you had no wish to give me pain, dear Suzanne. You have only called up some dreadful things that I am trying to forget. I am the daughter of a count. My childhood and youth were passed in châteaux and palaces, surrounded by every pleasure that an immense fortune could supply. As the wife of a viscount I have been received at court; I have been the companion of princesses. To-day all that is a dreadful dream. Before me I have a future the most modest and humble. I am the wife of Joseph the gardener; but poor and humble as is my present lot, I would not exchange it for the brilliant past, hidden from me by a veil of blood and tears.
Some day I will write and send you my history; for I want to make it plain to you, Suzanne, that titles and riches do not make happiness, but that the poorest fate illumined by the fires of love is very often radiant with pleasure.
speaker: Alix

utterance: On board a flatboat, a breach of form is permissible.

utterance:
Ah, our turn! our turn, Françoise!
I will be the cavalier!

utterance: WE are going out of here together, but John and I will conduct you only to the door of the hut. Thence we shall return to the flatboat, and all that two men can do to save our fortune shall be done. You, monsieur, have enough to do to take care of your daughters. To you, M. Carpentier—to you, son Celestino, I give the care of these women and children.
speaker: Mario

utterance: I can take care of myself.
speaker: Maggie

utterance: You are four, well armed. This dog is worth two men. You have no risks to run; the danger, if there be any, will be with the boat. Seeing us divided, they may venture an attack; but one of you stand by the window that faces the shore. If one of those men in the hut leaves it, or shows a wish to do so, fire one pistol-shot out of the window, and we shall be ready for them; but if you are attacked, fire two shots and we will come. Now, forward!
speaker: Mario
addressee: Joseph Charpentier and papa and Maggie

utterance: Well, let us play Cinderella. The dresses of velvet, silk, and lace, the jewels, the slippers — all are in yonder chest. Listen, my dear girls. Upon the first signs of the Revolution my frightened mother left France and crossed into England. She took with her all her wardrobe, her jewels, the pictures from her bedroom, and part of her plate. She bought, before going, a quantity of silks and ribbons. . . . When I reached England my mother was dead, and all that she had possessed was restored to me by the authorities. My poor mother loved dress, and in that chest is all her apparel. Part of it I had altered for my own use; but she was much larger than I - taller than you. I can neither use them nor consent to sell them. If each of you will accept a ball toilet, you will make me very happy.
speaker: Alix

utterance: Yes, my daughter, these names represent true aristocrats, as noble in virtues as in blood. The count, he to whom I bear this letter, married Madelaine Victoire de Livilier. These are noble names.

speaker: Alix

utterance: I will use all my efforts for that, Mme. la Viscomtesse.
speaker: Joseph Charpentier

utterance: Not yet,"
speaker: Joseph Charpentier

utterance:
I have foreseen this and have prepared everything to save you, Mme.
la Viscomtesse, if you will but let me make myself well understood.
speaker: Joseph Charpentier

utterance: Oh, all, all! Do thou understand, Joseph, I will do everything thou desirest.
speaker: Alix

utterance: then it is necessary that you consent to take Joseph Carpentier for your spouse.
speaker: Joseph Charpentier

utterance: My son!
speaker: Catharine

utterance: Oh, you see,"
speaker: Joseph Charpentier

utterance: my mother herself accuses me, and you — you, madame, have no greater confidence in me. But that is nothing; I must save you at any price. We will go from here together; we will descend to the village; we will present ourselves at the mayoralty -
speaker: Joseph Charpentier

utterance: Let me speak, madame,"
speaker: Joseph Charpentier

utterance:
We have not a moment to lose. Yes, we will present ourselves at the mayoralty, and there I will espouse you, not as Claudine Leroy, but as Alix de Morainville. Once my wife you have nothing to fear. Having become one of the people, the people will protect you. After the ceremony, madame, I will hand you the certificate of our marriage, and you will tear it up the moment we shall have touched the soil of England. Keep it precious till then; it is your only safeguard. Nothing prevents me from going to England to find employment, and necessarily my wife will go with me.
Are you ready, madame ?
speaker: Joseph Charpentier

utterance: My noble child!
speaker: Catharine

utterance: You are not lowering yourself, my boy.
speaker: the mayor

utterance:
Allow me, my friends, to present to you my wife.
The Viscomtesse de Morainville no longer exists; hurrah for the Citoyenne Carpentier.
speaker: Joseph Charpentier

utterance: Keep it, madame,"
speaker: Joseph Charpentier

utterance: you can destroy it on your arrival in England.
speaker: Joseph Charpentier

utterance: What is it, dear Joseph ?
speaker: Alix

utterance: More bad news? What has happened to my nurse-mother? Speak, speak, Joseph!
speaker: Alix

utterance: Nothing, Mme. la Viscomtesse,” he replied. “My mother and Bastien, I hope, are well. It is of myself I wish to speak.
speaker: Joseph Charpentier

utterance: I am going to America, madame.
speaker: Joseph Charpentier

utterance: You go away ?
speaker: Alix

utterance: You go away?
speaker: Alix

utterance: And I, Joseph ?
speaker: Alix

utterance: You, madame?
speaker: Joseph Charpentier

utterance: You have money. The Revolution will soon be over, and you can return to your country. There you will find again your friends, your titles, your fortune.
speaker: Joseph Charpentier

utterance: Stop!
speaker: Alix

utterance: What shall I be in France? You well know my château, my palace are pillaged and burned, my parents are dead.
speaker: Alix

utterance: My mother and Bastien are in France,
speaker: Joseph Charpentier

utterance: But thou—thou, Joseph; what can I do without thee? Why have you accustomed me to your tenderness, to your protection, and now come threatening to leave me? Hear me plainly. If you go I go with you.
speaker: Alix

utterance: Alix-madame.
speaker: Joseph Charpentier

utterance: I have guessed your secret,
speaker: Alix

utterance: You seek to go because you love me because you fear you may forget that respect which you fancy you owe me. But after all I am your wife, Joseph. I have the right to follow thee, and I am going with thee.
speaker: Alix

utterance: My name,
speaker: Mary

utterance: is Mary.
speaker: Mary

utterance: No; I am a yellow girl. I belong to Mr. Louis Belmonti, who keeps this 'coffee-house.' He has owned me for four or five years. Before that?
speaker: Mary

utterance: Before that, I belonged to Mr. John Fitz Miller, who has the saw-mill down here by the convent. I always belonged to him.
speaker: Mary

utterance: You are not rightly a slave. Your name is Müller. You are of pure German blood. I knew your mother. I know you. We came to this country together on the same ship, twenty-five years ago.
speaker: Madame Karl Rouff

utterance: No, you must be mistaking me for some one else that I look like.
speaker: Mary

utterance: Come with me. Come up into Lafayette and see if I do not show you to others who will know you the moment they look at you.
speaker: Madame Karl Rouff

utterance: Why, it is two years since last I saw you. Is that a German woman? I know her!
speaker: Eva Kropp, née Hillsler

utterance: Well, if you know her, who is she?
speaker: Madame Karl Rouff

utterance: My God! the long-lost Salome Müller!
speaker: Eva Kropp, née Hillsler

utterance: Is not that one of the girls who was lost?
speaker: Frank Schuber

utterance: It is, it is. It is Salome Müller!
speaker: Eva Kropp, née Hillsler

utterance: Who is that?
speaker: narrator
addressee: a man packed against me in the press

utterance: Roselius,
speaker: a man packed against me in the press

utterance: Come with me into this other room.
speaker: Eva Kropp, née Hillsler

utterance: I have paid you my money for her.
speaker: Louis Belmonti

utterance: But I did not sell her to you as a slave. She is as white as you or I, and neither of us can hold her if she chooses to go away.
speaker: John Fitz Miller

utterance: It is therefore ordered, adjudged, and decreed, that the judgment of the District Court be reversed; and ours is that the plaintiff be released from the bonds of slavery, that the defendants pay the costs of the appeal, and that the case be remanded for further proceedings as between the defendant and his warrantor.
speaker: the court

utterance: The question of damage,
speaker: the Law Reporter

utterance:
is the subjectmatter of another suit now pending against Jno. F.
Miller and Mrs. Canby.
speaker: the Law Reporter

utterance: Miss and I tried to get permission to see the interior. Madame said the landlord had requested her not to allow visitors; that over three hundred had called last winter, and had been refused for that reason. I thought of the three thousand who would call if they knew its story.
speaker: a friend

utterance: The landlord's orders are positive that no photographer of any kind shall come into his house.
speaker: another friend

utterance: It made me shudder,
speaker: a young girl

utterance: until I reasoned the matter out,
speaker: a young girl

utterance: Think of casting upon that woman the suspicion of starving and maltreating her own house-servants! Look at that driver; his skin shines with good keeping. The truth is those jealous Americans
speaker: some friend

utterance: Why, look you, it is her common practice, even before her guests, to leave a little wine in her glass and hand it, with some word of kindness, to the slave waiting at her back. Thin and hollow-chested-the slaves?
speaker: some friend

utterance:
Yes, to be sure; but how about your rich uncle, or my dear old mother; are they not hollow-chested?
Well!
speaker: some friend

utterance: Do you see this splendid house? Do you see those attic windows? There are slaves up there confined in chains and darkness and kept at the point of starvation.
speaker: the common populace

utterance: Slaves who shall not be properly fed, clad, and provided for by their masters, may give information thereof to the attorney-general or the Superior Council, or to all the other officers of justice of an inferior jurisdiction, and may put the written exposition of their wrongs into their hands; upon which information, and even ex officio, should the information come from another quarter, the attorney-general shall prosecute said masters,
speaker: Article XX. of the old Black Code

utterance: This way,
speaker: Madame Lalaurie

utterance: this way! Take this-go, now, and hurry back, if you please. This way!
speaker: Madame Lalaurie

utterance: This way, please, gentlemen; that is only the servants' quarters.

utterance: Those servants are chained and locked up and liable to perish.

utterance: In the garret rooms.

utterance: I am told

utterance: so and so can it be? Will you speak to Monsieur or to Madame?
speaker: Judge Canonge

utterance: Here, Montreuil, and you, Fernandez, will you go to the garret and search? I am blind and half smothered.
speaker: Judge Canonge

utterance: I have found some of them! I have broken some bars, but the doors are locked!
speaker: Felix Lefebre

utterance: Break the doors down!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Are there slaves still in your garret, Monsieur ?
speaker: Judge Canonge

utterance: There are persons who would do much better by remaining at home than visiting others to dictate to them laws in the quality of officious friends.
speaker: Dr. Louis Lalaurie

utterance: We saw,
speaker: the editor of the "Advertiser"

utterance:
one of these miserable beings.
The sight was so horrible that we could scarce look upon it. The most savage heart could not have witnessed the spectacle unmoved. He had a large hole in his head; his body from head to foot was covered with scars and filled with worms! The sight inspired us with so much horror that even at the moment of writing this article we shudder from its effects. Those who have seen the others represent them to be in a similar condition.
speaker: the editor of the "Advertiser"

utterance: "Turn the coach over!"

utterance: "Drag her out!"

utterance: "Stop her! Stop her! Stop that carriage! Stop that carriage!"
speaker: the crowd

utterance:
"As I live, there she goes now, on her regular drive!
What scandalous speed! and see here! they are after her!"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "No, no!"
speaker: a survivor

utterance: "we would n't have allowed that!"
speaker: a survivor

utterance: "knew nothing about it."
speaker: the hostess

utterance: "It was my mother's comb!"
speaker: Marguerite

utterance: "We have come to remove the colored pupils. You will call your school to order."
speaker: the White Leaguer

utterance: "You will permit me first to confer with my corps of associates."
speaker: the principal

utterance: "Oh, certainly."
speaker: the White Leaguer

utterance: "Ladies, we are waiting. Assemble the school; we are going to clean it out."
speaker: the White Leaguer

utterance: "Gentlemen, the school is assembled."
speaker: the principal

utterance: "Call the roll, and we will challenge each name."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "I am of Indian blood, and can prove it!"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "You will not be disturbed."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "My mother is white."
speaker: Coralie

utterance: "Step aside!"
speaker: the White Leaguer

utterance: "But by the law the color follows the mother, and so I am white."
speaker: Coralie

utterance: "Step aside!"
speaker: the White Leaguer

utterance: "Are you colored?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Yes; I am colored."
speaker: Octavie

utterance: "I am the sister of the Hon. naming a high Democratic official, and I shall not leave this school."
speaker: Marie O

utterance: "You may remain; your case will be investigated."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Step aside."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "I am not colored! We are Spanish, and my brother will call on you and prove it."
speaker: Marcelline V

utterance: "Now, madam, you will dismiss these pupils that we have set aside, at once. We will go down and wait to see that they come out."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Oh, save us! We cannot go out there; the mob will kill us! What shall we do?"
speaker: the girls who had been ordered into the street

utterance: "Have pity on me, Miss "
speaker: Léontine

utterance: "My poor Léontine, what can I do? There are good 'colored' schools in the city; would it not have been wiser for your father to send you to one of them ?"
speaker: the teacher

utterance: "Must I go to school with my own servants to escape an unmerited disdain ?"
speaker: Léontine

utterance: "The shame of it will kill me!"
speaker: Eugénie

utterance: "If Eugénie goes, Marcelline shall go, if I have to put her out myself! Spanish, indeed! And Eugénie a pearl by the side of her!"
speaker: a teacher

utterance: "Tie your veil close, Eugénie, and they will not know you."
speaker: the teacher

utterance: "Why don't the rest come?"
speaker: the crowd

utterance: "Come; the reporters will soon be here. Let us go and see after Marguerite."
speaker: a teacher

utterance: "Do you think that mere fright and the loss of that comb made this strong girl ill?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "No. I think she must have guessed those men's errand, and her eye met the eye of some one who knew her."
speaker: the janitress

utterance: "But what of that?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "She is 'colored."
speaker: the janitress

utterance: "Impossible!"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "I tell you, yes!"
speaker: the janitress

utterance: "Why, I thought her as pure German as her name."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "No, the mixture is there; though the only trace of it is on her lips. Her mother she is dead now was a beautiful quadroon. A German sea-captain loved her. The law stood between them. He opened a vein in his arm, forced in some of her blood, went to court, swore he had African blood, got his license, and married her. Marguerite is engaged to be married to a white man, a gentleman who does not know this. It was like life and death, so to speak, for her not to let those men turn her out of here."
speaker: the janitress

utterance:
I am busy, but
-has anybody-has anything happened to-to anybody in Madame Brouillard's house?
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: Yes, ce Michié qui poté soulié jaune-that gentleman who wears yellow shoes is ill. Madame Brouillard is hurrying to and fro and crying.
speaker: Attalie's black slave girl

utterance: Very loud?
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: No, silently; yet as though her heart were breaking.
speaker: Attalie's black slave girl

utterance: And the doctor?
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: was there yesterday and the day before.
speaker: Attalie's black slave girl

utterance: Li bien malade, he is very ill.
speaker: Attalie Brouillard

utterance: wants to make his will?
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance:
Attalie Attalie-I want to leave it all to you
- what little
speaker: John Bull

utterance: Bring a notary.
speaker: John Bull

utterance: And the doctor?
speaker: Attalie Brouillard

utterance: has not come to-day. Michié told the doctor if he came again he would kick him downstairs. Yes, and the doctor says whenever a patient of his says that he stops coming.
speaker: Attalie Brouillard

utterance: He has dropped asleep.
speaker: Attalie Brouillard

utterance: If you make a noise, or in any way let any one know what has happened, it will cost you all he is worth. I will leave you alone with him just ten minutes.
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: What do you mean?
speaker: Attalie Brouillard

utterance: Hush! you speak too loud. He is dead.
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: Come, there is not a moment to lose.
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: What do you want?
speaker: Attalie Brouillard

utterance: I must make haste to fulfill the oft-repeated request of my friend here.
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: Your friend!
speaker: Attalie Brouillard

utterance: Our friend; yes, this man here. You did not know that I was his secret confidential adviser? Well, that was all right; I told him to tell no one. But now I must carry out his instructions. Madame Brouillard, this man wished to leave you every cent he had in the world.
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: He may never have told you so till to-day, but he has often told me. 'I tell you, Camille,' he used to say, 'because I can trust you: I can't trust a white man in a matter like this.' He told you? Yes; then you know that I speak the truth. But one thing you did not know; that this intention of his was the result of my earnest advice.- Stop! Madame Brouillardif you please we have no time for amazement or questions now; and less than none for expressions of gratitude. Listen to me. You know he was always afraid he would die some day suddenly? Yes, of course; everybody knew that. One night-our meetings were invariably at night-he said to me, 'Camille, my dear friend, if I should go all of a sudden some day before I write that will, you know what to do.' Those were his exact words: 'Camille, my dear friend, you know what to do.'
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: Madame, are your lodgers all up town?
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: Good. And you have but the one servant. Go tell her that our dear friend has been in great suffering but is now much better, quite free from pain, in fact, and wants to attend to some business. Send her to Exchange alley, to the office of Eugene Favre. He is a notary public
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: Understand?
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: She must tell him, to come at once. But before she goes there she must stop on the way and tell three persons to come and witness a notarial act. Now whom shall they be? For they must be white male residents of the parish, and they must not be insane, deaf, dumb, blind, nor disqualified by crime. I will tell you: let them be Jean d'Eauat the French market. He will still be there; it is his turn to scrub the market to-day. Get him, get Richard Reau, and old man Ecswyzee. And on no account must the doctor be allowed to come. Do that, Madame Brouillard, as quickly as you can. I will wait here.
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: What are you going to do, Michié Ducour?
speaker: Attalie Brouillard

utterance: We are going to make you sole legatee.
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance:
I do not want it! How are you going to do it?
How?
speaker: Attalie Brouillard

utterance: In a way which he knows about and approves.
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: I cannot leave him. Do what you please, only let me stay here. Oh! let me stay here.
speaker: Attalie Brouillard

utterance: I see, like all women, you count the foolish sentiments of the living of more value than the reasonable wish of the dead.
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance:
Come. Go.
And make haste to get back again; we are losing priceless time.
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: Well?
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: O Michié Ducour! those three witnesses will never do. I am in debt to every one of them!
speaker: Attalie Brouillard

utterance: Madame Brouillard, the one you owe the most to will be the best witness. Well? What next?
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance:
O my dear friend! what is this going to cost?
in money, I mean. I am so afraid of lawyers' accounts!
I have nothing, and if it turns out that he has very, very little-It is true that I sent for you, but-I did not think you what must you charge?
speaker: Attalie Brouillard

utterance:
Nothing! Madame Brouillard, whether he leaves you little or much, this must be for me a labor of love to him who was secretly my friend, or I will not touch it. He certainly had something, however, or he would not have tried to write a will. But, my dear madame, if you do not right here, now, stop looking scared, as if you were about to steal something instead of saving something from being stolen, it will cost us a great deal. Go. Make haste!
That's right!-Ts-s-st! Hold on! Which is your own bedroom, upstairs?-Never mind why I ask; tell me.
Yes; all right! Now, go!-Ts-s-st! Bring my hat up as you return.
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: My God! you have not, yourself, already?
speaker: Attalie Brouillard

utterance:
I could not wait, Madame Brouillard. We must run up now, and do for him whatever cannot be put off; and then you must let me come back, leaving my hat and shoes and coat up there, and stand?
-you under
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: And now, Madame Brouillard, to do this thing in the very best way I ought to say to you at once that our dear friend did he ever tell you what he was worth?
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: No, ah! no, no, no! that was none of my business. He was going to leave it all to me. I never asked if it was little or much.
speaker: Attalie Brouillard

utterance: Well, Madame Brouillard, the plain fact is he was as you may say poor.
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance: Alas! I feared it. That is what I feared. But ah! since it makes no difference to him now, it makes little to me. I feared it. That accounts for his leaving it to me, poor milatraise.
speaker: Attalie Brouillard

utterance: But would you have imagined, madame, that all he had was barely three thousand dollars?
speaker: Camille Ducour

utterance:
Ah! three thousand-ah! Michié Ducour, that is not so little.
Three thousand! In Paris, where my brother lives, that would be fifteen thousand francs. Ah! Michié Ducour, I never guessed half that much, Michié Ducour, I tell you - he was too good to be rich.
speaker: Attalie Brouillard

speaker: Attalie Brouillard

utterance: Mr. Ducour, as friends of Mr. [Englishman] we desire to express our satisfaction at the terms of his last will and testament. We have had a long talk with Madame Brouillard; but for myself, I already know his wish that she should have whatever he might leave. But a wish is one thing; a will, even a nuncupative will by public act, is another and an infinitely better and more effective thing. But we wish also to express our determination to see that you are not hindered in the execution of any of the terms of this will, whose genuineness we, of course, do not for a moment question.
speaker: the stranger

utterance: No
speaker: the fourth man

utterance: I am the custodian of all Mr. [Englishman's] accounts and assets. This gentleman is a judge, this one is a lawyer, I believe you know them all by sight, this one is a banker, and this one a in fact, a detective. We wish you to feel at all times free to call upon any or all of us for advice, and to bear in mind that our eyes are ever on you with a positively solicitous interest. You are a busy man, Mr. Ducour, living largely by your wits, and we must not detain you longer. We are glad that you are yourself to receive fifteen hundred dollars. We doubt not you have determined to settle the affairs of the estate without other remuneration, and we not mere
speaker: the stranger

utterance: Come, G., leave your church for to-day and come Iwith us to hear Dr. on the situation. He will convince you.
speaker: Mrs. F.

utterance: It is good to be convinced, I will go.
speaker: G.

utterance: Now, G., you heard him prove from the Bible that slavery is right and that therefore secession is. Were you not convinced?
speaker: Mrs. F.

utterance: I was so busy thinking how completely it proved too that Brigham Young is right about polygamy that it quite weakened the force of the argument for me.
speaker: G.

utterance: G., I believe these are your sentiments
speaker: Rob

utterance: Well, what do you expect? This is not their quarrel
speaker: G.

utterance: Rob, keep cool; don't let that threat excite you. Cotton is king. Just wait till they feel the pinch a little; their tone will change.
speaker: Rob's father

utterance: G., first come and help me dress Phoebe and Chloe [the negro servants]. There is a ball to-night in aristocratic colored society. This is Chloe's first introduction to New Orleans circles, and Henry Judson, Phoebe's husband, gave five dollars for a ticket for her.
speaker: Edith

utterance: G., run into your room, please, and write a pass for Henry. Put Mr. D.'s name to it.
speaker: Edith

utterance: Why, Henry is free
speaker: G.

utterance: That makes no difference; all colored people must have a pass if out late. They choose a master for protection and always carry his pass. Henry chose Mr. D., but he's lost the pass he had.
speaker: Edith

utterance: How can you speak so plainly before them?
speaker: G.

utterance: Why, what matter? They know that we shall keep the whip-handle.
speaker: unclear

utterance: No, gentlemen; the day we seceded the star of our glory set.
speaker: Uncle Ralph

utterance: You did n't kiss your little sweetheart
speaker: Edith's husband

utterance: I don't approve of your war and won't help you, particularly in the murderous part of it.
speaker: G.

utterance: Never fear, my dear madame, Texas alone can furnish butter enough to supply the whole Confederacy; we'll soon be getting it from there.
speaker: a school official

utterance: You see, my prophecy is coming true that Virginia will be the seat of war.
speaker: Mrs. D.

utterance: Indeed, you may think yourselves lucky if this war turns out to have any seat in particular.
speaker: G.

utterance: O G.! three thousand of our own, dear Southern boys are lying out there.
speaker: Mrs. F.

utterance: My dear Fannie, they are heroes now. They died in a glorious cause, and it is not in vain. This will end it. The sacrifice had to be made, but those killed have gained immortal names.
speaker: Mr. F.

utterance: Victory!
speaker: Edith

utterance: Do not look so gloomy, G.. You should be happy to-night; for, as Mr. F. says, now we shall have peace.
speaker: Mr. S.

utterance: And is that the way you think of the men of your own blood and race?
speaker: G.

utterance: Ah! G., you are just in time to help us; these are coats for Jeff Thompson's men. All the cloth in the city is exhausted; these flannel-lined oilcloth table-covers are all we could obtain to make overcoats for Thompson's poor boys. They will be very warm and serviceable.
speaker: Mrs. F.

utterance: Serviceable, yes! The Federal army will fly when they see those coats! I only wish I could be with the regiment when these are shared around.
speaker: G.

utterance: We pitched the Yankees over the bluff
speaker: Rob

utterance: G., you are just as pertinacious yourself in championing your opinions. What sustains you when nobody agrees with you?
speaker: Rob

utterance: Alex, I was up at your orange-lots to-day and the sour oranges are dropping to the ground, while they cannot get lemons for our sick soldiers.
speaker: Edith

utterance: That's my kind, considerate wife. Why did n't I think of that before? Jim shall fill some barrels to-morrow and take them to the hospitals as a present from you.
speaker: Mr. D.

utterance: You are a black-hearted traitor, My money is just as good as coin you'll see! Go to Yankee land. It will suit you better with your sordid views and want of faith, than the generous South.
speaker: a young lady teacher

utterance: Well, when I think of going, I'll come to you for a letter of introduction to your grandfather in Yankee land.
speaker: G.

utterance: Wish to search for arms? Certainly, gentlemen.
speaker: Dr. B.

utterance: Mrs. L., are you not going to send your husband? Now use a young bride's influence and persuade him; he would be elected one of the officers.
speaker: Mrs. A.

utterance: Mrs. A., the Bible says, 'When a man hath married a new wife, he shall not go to war for one year, but remain at home and cheer up his wife.'
speaker: Mrs. L.

utterance: can you stand the pressure, or shall you be forced into volunteering?
speaker: Mrs. L.

utterance: Indeed, I will not be bullied into enlisting by women, or by men. I will sooner take my chance of conscription and feel honest about it. You know my attachments, my interests are here; these are my people. I could never fight against them; but my judgment disapproves their course, and the result will inevitably be against us.
speaker: H.

utterance: So, Mike, you are really going to be a soldier?
speaker: H.

utterance: Yes, sor; but faith, Mr. L., I don't see the use of me going to shtop a bullet when sure an' I'm willin' for it to go where it plazes.
speaker: Mike

utterance: She asked if there were any new fashions in New Orleans.
speaker: narrator

utterance: We know what you have said of us, and I have come to tell you that you are liars, and you know where to find us.
speaker: Mr. R.

utterance: It's a serenade, H. Get up and bring out all the wine you have.
speaker: Mr. R.

utterance: Laws, Mis' L., I nebber done bin nigh dem hens. Mis' Annie, you can go count dem dere eggs.
speaker: Reeney

utterance: Well, is the war over?
speaker: Mrs. L.

utterance: Oh, I got sick!
speaker: Max

utterance: I suppose, H., you've heard that Island No. 10 is gone?
speaker: Mrs. L.

utterance: Well, my arrangements are completed. You can begin to pack your trunks to-morrow, and I shall have a talk with Max.
speaker: H.

utterance: Heard the news?
speaker: Mr. R. and Annie

utterance: No! What news?
speaker: Mrs. L.

utterance: H., that man has come here to hide from the conscript officers. He has brought no end of provisions, and is here for the war. He has chosen well, for this county is so cleaned of men it won't pay to send the conscript officers here.
speaker: Max

utterance: Listen to that running water; what is it?
speaker: Mrs. L.

utterance: Max, get up! The water is on us!
speaker: H.

utterance: W'at I dun tole you fum de fust?
speaker: Aunt Judy

utterance: They said to me, "We will not see your family starve, Mr. R.; but with such numbers of slaves and the village poor to feed, we can spare nothing for sale."
speaker: Max

utterance: Well, of course, we do not purpose to stay here and live on charity rations. We must leave the place at all hazards. We have studied out every route and made inquiries everywhere we went. We shall have to go down the Mississippi in an open boat as far as Fetler's Landing (on the eastern bank). There we can cross by land and put the boat into Steele's Bayou, pass thence to the Yazoo River, from there to Chickasaw Bayou, into McNutt's Lake, and land near my uncle's in Warren County.
speaker: H.

utterance: I wonder, when I shall ever have nicely starched clothes after these? They had no starch in Natchez or Vicksburg when I was there.
speaker: Annie

utterance: Don't row so fast; we may run against something.
speaker: H.

utterance: I'm hardly pulling at all.
speaker: Max

utterance: Then we're in what she called the rapids !
speaker: H.

utterance: look out for the rapids.
speaker: the neatly dressed woman

utterance: Who are you? What do you want?
speaker: A negro

utterance: Travelers seeking shelter for the night.
speaker: Max and H.

utterance: I'll let nobody in. The Yankees have been here and took twenty-five of my negroes to work on their fortifications, and I've no beds nor anything for anybody.
speaker: the master

utterance:
Oh! my soul's brother from youth up is a traitor!
A traitor to his country!
speaker: Max

utterance: Max, don't be a fool!
speaker: H.

utterance: Who has done this? You felt with the South at first; who has changed you?
speaker: Max

utterance: Of course I feel for the South now, and nobody has changed me but the logic of events, though the twenty-negro law has intensified my opinions. I can't see why I, who have no slaves, must go to fight for them, while every man who has twenty may stay at home.
speaker: H.

utterance:
Max, what interest has a man like you, without slaves, in a war for slavery? Even if you had them, they would not be your best property.
That lies in your country and its resources. Nearly all the world has given up slavery; why can't the South do the same and end the struggle? It has shown you what the South needs, and if all went to work with united hands the South would soon be the greatest country on earth. You have no right to call H. a traitor; it is we who are the true patriots and lovers of the South.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Oh, you 'll get bravely over that. I used to be a Jewess about pork, but now we just kill a hog and eat it, and kill another and do the same. It's all we have.
speaker: the acquaintance

utterance: Oh, not young ones. Old ones might run off when the enemy's lines approach ours, but with young ones there is no danger.
speaker: a gentleman

utterance: Do yours know it?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Oh, yes. Finding it to be known elsewhere, I told it to mine with fair warning what to expect if they tried to run away. The hounds are not far off.
speaker: Mr. W.

utterance: Just let him try to enforce it and they'll cow-hide him. He'll get none from me. I'll take care of my own friends without an order from him.
speaker: Mrs. W.

utterance: Well, if the South is defeated and the slaves set free, the Southern people will all become atheists, for the Bible justifies slavery and says it shall be perpetual.
speaker: Mr. W.

utterance: You mean, if the Lord does not agree with you, you'll repudiate him.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Well, we 'll feel it's no use to believe in anything.
speaker: Mr. W.

utterance: I shall give Mr. W. a piece of my mind. He must have taken leave of his senses!
speaker: Bessie J.

utterance: What is the matter, Bessie ?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Why, G., don't you know whom you've been sitting at table with?
speaker: Bessie J.

utterance: That stranger, you mean; I suppose Mr. W. forgot to introduce him.
speaker: narrator

utterance:
Forgot! He knew better than to introduce him!
That man is a nigger-chaser. He's got his bloodhounds here now.
speaker: Bessie J.

utterance: Did you see the dogs?
speaker: narrator

utterance: No, I asked Hester if he had them, and she said, 'Yes.' Think of Mr. W. bringing him to table with us. If my brothers knew it there would be a row.
speaker: Bessie J.

utterance: Where are your brothers? At college still?
speaker: narrator

utterance: No, in the army; Pa told them they'd have to come and fight to save their property. His men cost him twelve to fifteen hundred dollars apiece and are too valuable to lose.
speaker: Bessie J.

utterance: Well, I would n't worry about this man, he may be useful some day to save that kind of property.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Of course, you can take it easily, you're going away; but if Mr. W. thinks I'm going to sit at table with that wretch he 's vastly mistaken.
speaker: Bessie J.

utterance: Don't cry so, you'll find him yet.
speaker: the conductor

utterance: There he is now!
speaker: the young woman

utterance: But the worst thing was, they would take every tooth-brush in the house, because we can't buy any more; and one cavalry man put my sister's new bonnet on his horse, and said 'Get up, Jack,' and her bonnet was gone.
speaker: a friend

utterance: It is such folly for them to waste their ammunition like that. How can they ever take a town that has such advantages for defense and protection as this? We'll just burrow into these hills and let them batter away as hard as they please.
speaker: a lady

utterance: You are right, madam; and besides, when our women are so willing to brave death and endure discomfort, how can we ever be conquered ?
speaker: an officer

utterance: The only drawback are the contemptible men who are staying at home in comfort when they ought to be in the army if they had a spark of honor.
speaker: a lady

utterance: We do not keep a hotel, but would willingly feed hungry soldiers if we had the food.
speaker: narrator

utterance: I have been traveling all night and am starving; will pay any price for just bread.
speaker: a person

utterance: It was a wonder you did n't have your heads taken off last night. I passed and saw them stretched over the gallery, and grape-shot were whizzing up the street just on a level with you.
speaker: a friend

utterance: Oh! Miss G., my child is killed and the kitchen tore up.
speaker: Martha

utterance: Yes, it's no use hollerin', old lady.
speaker: Confederate soldiers

utterance: Oh! H., America is wounded.
speaker: narrator

utterance: That is no news; she has been wounded by traitors long ago.
speaker: H.

utterance:
Oh, this is real, living, little, black America.
I am not talking in symbols. Here are the pieces of shell, the first bolt of the coming siege.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Now you see that this house will be but paper to mortar-shells. You must go into the country.
speaker: H.

utterance: Who lives here?
speaker: the orderly

utterance: Mr. L.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Which Mr. L.?
speaker: the orderly

utterance: Mr. H. L.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Is he here?
speaker: the orderly

utterance: No.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Where can he be found?
speaker: the orderly

utterance: At the office of Deputy
speaker: narrator

utterance: I'm not going there. This is an order from General Pemberton for you to move out of this house in two hours. He has selected it for headquarters. He will furnish you with wagons.
speaker: the orderly

utterance: Will he furnish another house also?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Of course not.
speaker: the orderly

utterance: Has the owner been consulted?
speaker: narrator

utterance: He has not; that is of no consequence; it has been taken. Take this order.
speaker: the orderly

utterance: I shall not take it, and I shall not move, as there is no place to move to but the street.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Then I'll take it to Mr. L.
speaker: the orderly

utterance: Very well, do so.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Hold the fort till I've seen the owner and the general.
speaker: H.

utterance: Landlord says, 'Keep them out. Would n't let them have his house at any price.' He is just riding off to the country and can't help us now. Now I'm going to see Major C., who sent the order.
speaker: H.

utterance: Oh! what's this?
speaker: the fattest one

utterance: Ah, madam! are you aware I had the right to break down this door if you had n't opened it?
speaker: the fattest one

utterance: That would make no difference to me. I'm not the owner. You or the landlord would pay the bill for the repairs.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Why did n't you open the door?
speaker: the fattest one

utterance: Have I not done so as soon as you rung? A lady does not open the door to men who beat on it. Gentlemen usually ring; I thought it might be stragglers pounding.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Well, we are going to send you some wagons to move; you must get ready.
speaker: the fattest one

utterance: With pleasure, if you have selected a house for me. This is too large; it does not suit me.
speaker: narrator

utterance: No, I did n't find a house for you.
speaker: the fattest one

utterance: You surely don't expect me to run about in the dust and shelling to look for it, and Mr. L. is too busy.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Well, madam, then we must share the house. We will take the lower floor.
speaker: the fattest one

utterance: I prefer to keep the lower floor myself; you surely don't expect me to go up and down stairs when you are so light and more able to do it.
speaker: narrator

utterance: What room is that?
speaker: the fattest one

utterance: The parlor.
speaker: narrator

utterance: And this?
speaker: the fattest one

utterance: My bedroom.
speaker: narrator

utterance: And this?
speaker: the fattest one

utterance: The diningroom.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Well, madam, we'll find you a house and then come and take this.
speaker: the fattest one

utterance: Thank you, colonel. I shall be ready when you find the house. Good morning, sir.
speaker: narrator

utterance: We must go back, captain; you see I didn't know they were this kind of people.
speaker: the fattest one

utterance: Well, Mr. L., they are upon us; the Yankees will be here by this evening.
speaker: Mr. J.

utterance: What do you mean?
speaker: H.

utterance: That Pemberton has been whipped at Baker's Creek and Big Black, and his army are running back here as fast as they can come and the Yanks after them, in such numbers nothing can stop them. Has n't Pemberton acted like a fool?
speaker: Mr. J.

utterance: He may not be the only one to blame.
speaker: H.

utterance: They're coming along the Big B. road, and my folks went down there to be safe, you know; now they're right in it. I hear you can't see the armies for the dust; never was anything else known like it. But I must go and try to bring my folks back here.
speaker: Mr. J.

utterance: What is the news?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Ritreat, ritreat!
speaker: worn-out-looking men

utterance: Run!
speaker: H.

utterance: Where?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Back!
speaker: H.

utterance: Oh, madam, there was never anything so good! I shall get better.
speaker: the soldier

utterance: G., it seems to me I can hear the silence, and feel it too. It wraps me like a soft garment; how else can I express this peace?
speaker: H.

utterance: Mr. L., you must both come to our cave to-night. I hear that to-night the shelling is to surpass anything yet. An assault will be made in front and rear. You know we have a double cave; there is room for you in mine, and mother and sister will make a place for Mrs. L. Come right up; the ball will open about seven.
speaker: Mr. J.

utterance: This is strangely quiet, Mr. L.
speaker: H.

utterance: Ah, sir, I'm afraid the last shell has been thrown into Vicksburg.
speaker: the editor of the "Daily Citizen"

utterance: Why do you fear so?
speaker: H.

utterance: It is surrender. At six last evening a man went down to the river and blew a truce signal; the shelling stopped at once.
speaker: the editor of the "Daily Citizen"

utterance: Good-morning, madam, we won't bother you much longer. We can't thank you enough for letting us come, for getting this soup boiled has helped some of us to keep alive, but now all this is over.
speaker: the soldier

utterance: Is it true about the surrender?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Yes; we have had no official notice, but they are paroling out at the lines now, and the men in Vicksburg will never forgive Pemberton. An old granny! A child would have known better than to shut men up in this cursed trap to starve to death like useless vermin. Have n't I seen my friends carted out three or four in a box, that had died of starvation! Nothing else, madam! Starved to death because we had a fool for a general.
speaker: the soldier

utterance: Don't you think you 're rather hard on Pemberton? He thought it his duty to wait for Johnston.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Some people may excuse him, ma'am, but we'll curse him to our dying day. Anyhow, you'll see the blue-coats directly.
speaker: the soldier

utterance: H., do you think these can be the Federal sol-diers?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Why, yes; here come more up the street.
speaker: H.

utterance: Now I feel once more at home in my own country.
speaker: H.

utterance: What can this mean, H.? Are the populace turning out to greet the despised conquerors?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Oh, look! It is the boats coming around the bend.
speaker: H.

utterance: Aren't you coming, Mr. L.? There's provisions on those boats: coffee and flour. 'First come, first served,' you know.
speaker: Mr. J.

utterance: Yes, I'll be there pretty soon.
speaker: H.
